When it is asked, what particular reasons may have led Tacitus to choose this particular subject lor such separate treatment, the explana- tion is naturally sought in those parts ol the treatise which show most evidence of being written with a purpose: hence some have supposed, from the descriptions ol German hardihood and courage, andos the disasters which Rome had suffered at their hands ⁴, that he desired to turn men’s thoughts from any idea of subjugating them ; others, that he intended to lash the vices ol effete civilization by contrast with the virtues ol healthy barbarism⁵; such explanations being plainly too partial to account for the treatise as a whole, which we cannot suppose to have been written lor the mere purpose os bringing in a few telling passages

The abrupt beginning and ending of the work¹ have suggested the idea that it was written lor insertion in the Histories ⁶, and was lor some reason afterwards taken out and published separately. The ‘situs gentium' is certainly reekoned by Tacitus among the proper subjects of history⁷3 and we have evidence of his practice in the account of Britain in the Agricola⁸ and of the Jews in the Histories⁹, as well as of that ol other writers ¹⁰.
